section.text: In music, the verb invert means to move the lowest note in a group an octave higher.
In this lesson, we will be inverting intervals.
For our first example, we will use the interval of C to G (a perfect fifth).
To invert this interval, move the lowest note (the C) an octave higher.
The result (G to C) is a perfect fourth.
Perfects will always invert to perfects. Fourths will always invert to fifths.
For our next example, we will use C to E (a major third).
Again, move the lowest note (the C) an octave higher.
The result (E to C) is a minor sixth.
Majors and minors will always invert to each other - as will thirds and sixths. For example, a minor third will always invert to a major sixth.
Next, we will invert C to B (a major seventh).
Yet again, move the lowest note an octave higher
The result (B to C) is a minor second.
Seconds and sevenths will always invert to each other.
The final rule of interval inversion states that augmented and diminished intervals always invert to each other.
For example, C to F# (an augmented fourth), results in F# to C (a diminished fifth).
